text: I hate watching Modern...it's all thoughtsieze's and hand disruption because everyone's afraid of other's playing magic. Hand disruption is basically admitting you made bad deckbuilding choices so you have to stop others from playing because you can't deal with their decks. I also recognize I come across as a crazy old man yelling at those damn kids to get off my lawn, but there it is.
Do counterspells mean the same thing? Because Thoughtsieze is a preemptive counterspell
Yup...basically.
A little difference since hand disruption lets you see your opponent's hand, so you get knowledge counterspells don't necessarily give you.
I know my opinion isn't popular or common, but there it is.
It's also why I don't play competitive magic...really not suited to my personality.
If they made a Thoughtsieze that could hit each opponent, I would play that in EDH. I love hand disruption.
Of course you do
Play your own magic man...make better deckbuilding choices :wink:
I do. By taking away your best options. Preemptive removal
Nah...you're taking away things you likely don't have an answer for if it hit the table, again, because you made bad deckbuilding choices... :wink:
I'm in mono black. How else do you expect me to deal with artifacts and enchantments?
You take your lumps. You chose to play mono-black. I play it and know the weaknesses.
Also, taking away things I don't otherwise have an answer for... How can you fault me for that? That's the definition of out valuing your opponents
Don't you love value?
Be faster with your strategy and get there before them.

Is there really that much difference between making an opponent discard their sol ring and disenchanting their sol ring? Each is taking something away from an opponent, just in a different way Maro demands the color pie to do

It’s the whole “doom blade vs Counterspell” argument. Countering / Discarding prevents any gain in value.
My favorite example is Siege Rhino.
Countering it is great because you don’t have to deal with it. Removal is less great because you’ve already taken 3

Yes because you were able to make the decision with better information as to their resources and options so you can make a more informed decision. Responding to their sol Ring leaves room for more variance and for the opponent to play around your removal vs if you flat out know what they have.
It’s very different.
So, you're argument boils down to "It's not fair that you get better removal than me"?
No, my argument is it removes variance from the game and lessens the strategic aspect. One-sided perfect information has a way of doing that.
It seems like a "method vs principle" argument here. Removal is fine, the method that you do it is where your issue is

What if you play gitaxian probe or something that lets you see the opponents hand? Then if you counter something, couldn't you say you had perfect information then too? Which makes it just as egregious
I don’t like probe either.
Again, it’s not my style of play. I’m allowed to not like things. :smiling_imp:
Solve all your problems. Run [[!Telepathy]]
That removes part of the game’s fun for me. Perfect information is boring.
I didn't say you weren't allowed to dislike it. Just trying to understand your stance
It's political information. You can easily turn your opponents against each other. And your hand is still secret, so it's not truly perfect.
It would be cool if the card instead said "Your opponents' hands are not hidden zones."
I don’t want one-sided perfect information either.
I like the poker-aspect of the game. Trying to guess is part of the fun.
Libraries are still a big "what if"
Unless you Fractured Identity a Future Sight.
<@U3QMCLQQG> all I’m imagining now is an EDH game played with the rules of Hanabi
I’d rather folks not know anyone’s hand, outside of bounce, etc, and play accordingly.
Discard effects that are random or let the target choose are fine because it removes the perfect information aspect.
I love me some Syphon Mind
I’m all for forcing opponents to make tough/bad choices.
Kill the person
Is that a fair strategy?
Telepathy is a card I hate playing against but would love playing. I don’t like surprises :)
It can make for a dreadful table though
"you kept what!?"
I just meant it makes a mess, but that too

I dislike Telepathy from my early experiences of it. We had a Zedruu Control deck in our group at one point who never got targeted. He would just overseer the table and eventually win. To be fair, all but one player was relatively new and his deck was a well-oiled machine, so it didn’t necessarily make sense to target him. Hindsight is 20/20 and all.
Just saw this for the first time, seems funny [[!Guided Passage]]
It's a cool card.
Great in Riku

Buddy of mine uses that. It’s like a super [[Manifold Insights]]. Usually winds up with him getting a signet, mountain, and a Sakura, but occasionally someone gives him something they want him to use, like a removal spell or a board wipe

attachments.fallback: Manifold Insights {2}{U} // Sorcery // Reveal the top ten cards of your library. Starting with the next opponent in turn order, each opponent chooses a different nonland card from among them. Put the chosen cards into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.
attachments.text:
Sorcery
Reveal the top ten cards of your library. Starting with the next opponent in turn order, each opponent chooses a different nonland card from among them. Put the chosen cards into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in a random order.
attachments.title: Manifold Insights {2}{U}

text: Yeah, that was one of the Commanders mentioned (Riku)
It's actually too expensive to run in one of my 3DH budget decks O.O It's 1.01 TIX
Guided Passage is great. Even in a precon the worst land, creature and non-creature non-land card to hand for three is worth it
And plenty often people don't understand the worst choices to give.
Yeah, it's easy to politic your way into some good cards.
But even if they do pick the absolute worst choices it's still worth.

Casting it saying "Man, it'd be great if there was some removal for that Winter Orb, oh, person struggling with Winter Orb, would you like to be my target opponent? OH LOOK, MY DECIMATE WAS 10 CARDS DOWN, HOW FUNNY IS THAT?!"
Precisely.
"man, wouldn't it suck if I blew up only permanents controlled by Winter Orb player with that Decimate?"
"oh, I'm short on mana after casting Guided Passage...be a bro and let me get that Temple of the False God?"
"Like their Gaea's Cradle" MUAHAHAHAHAHAHA
I’m stuck in a game where the Tymna/Thrasios player has nothing but lands and a hand of 30+ cards and he just passes.
well, that’s not normal
I just want him to actually win so we can plan another game.
He just put Stifle under Isochron Scepter.
Tymna/Thrasios? I’m sorry you’re in that pod.
Thopter Foundry/Sword of the Meek combo incoming from him.
At this point I don’t care...just finish it.
That's the kind of thing that often happens to me.
Aaaaand...pass turn.
I take a turn to accrue all the pieces, but assembling the pieces is another turn or two.
Sorry bout it
He has nothing but tutors and about 20 lands...
He’s taken incredibly long turns all game.
It’s stupid and disrespectful to other players.
Kick him out of the next game >D
What is his actual wincon, though? Like... Does he have one?
Thopter sword is a wincon. He just needs to use it properly.
First time piloting the deck?
No. It’s time to bring out Xiahou Dun.
Xiahou Dun wins on turn 5 or 6 with Hatred.
I had Leyline of the Void and Waste Not in my opening hand.
And my first draw was Siphon Mind.
We were playing 5-player Sheriff so I only had to kill one player.
I hit magical Xmasland with Xiahou Dun. With Leyline and Waste Not out I drew into [[Oppression]]. It didn’t go well for everyone else after that.

attachments.fallback: Oppression {1}{B}{B} // Enchantment // Whenever a player casts a spell, that player discards a card.
attachments.text:
Enchantment
Whenever a player casts a spell, that player discards a card.
_"Defeating an enemy is not nearly as satisfying as watching one suffer." —The Western Paladin_
attachments.title: Oppression {1}{B}{B}

text: I drew soooo many cards off Waste Not.
I’m ashamed to admit that I agree with Oppressions’s flavor text. You just saw the light leave their eyes.
That's awesome.
In thinking about my enchantress decks next iteration
I kind of wanted to add blue, but most the bant options look boring
K&T i kinda want to try... but not sure how id win
Sliver queen would be similar to marath, in that it combos with mana echoes, earthcraft, purph etc. might be easier to combo even
If i go 5 color id have to cannibalize my foils from my mono black deck though....
I appreciate how Don gets that non-foil cards work worse than foils.
Judge foil Sol Rings actually tap for 3
There is even shit like imperial seal
Which i only have one of
Ihave a pecking order of deck optimizations and for a long time mbc and enhantress havent competed
Maybe that makes me want to do k&t in itsslf
Ive never even played against a k&t deck
What even actually happens?
Like doesnthe kt player generally ramp out more?

Depends on your build but my k&t is purely political. It’s generally pacifistic, draws everyone lots of cards, doesn’t let anyone go too crazy unless I want them too. I frequently use other people’s stuff to win the game. Reins of power, mob rule, treacherous terrain, insurrection, incite rebellion, selfless squire
Usually i have more mana than everyone but mostly I just want to have more options than everyone. I have an article on them I’m pretty proud of if you wanna know more
An iteration of my K&T deck is coming out in my next article.
It's Aikido control.
K&T manlands is something I considered also.
Wlel for me... its an enchantress theme trying to find a commander not the other way around
Ive done a bunch of 5c variations, marath, selesyna (sigarda)
How many enchantment decks have you done?
Branch out, Don
Have you done dovescape yet don?
Yup
[[kydele]] could be interestig
